intro: Coffea indica, commonly known as the Arabian coffee plant, is a species native to the highlands of Ethiopia and Yemen. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters, with dark green, oval-shaped leaves and white flowers. The plant produces red, fleshy berries that contain two seeds, which are the beans used for coffee. Coffea indica thrives in tropical climates with high altitudes, requiring well-drained soil and moderate rainfall. It is known for its unique aroma and flavor profile, which can vary depending on the growing conditions.
